Fig. 1 XRD patterns for fresh (a) and activated catalysts (b). Fig 1 Fig. 2 Dark field TEM micrographs for NiMo-CMgO-1 (a) and NiMo-HMgO-1 (b) and the corresponding EDS mapping of Ni, Mo, Mg and O elements. Fig 2 Fig. 3 TEM images for NiMo-HMgO-2a (a-b) and NiMo-HMgO-1a (c-d) with corresponding EDS mapping of Ni, Mo, Mg and O elements. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Stability evaluation of catalysts for DRM. (a) CH4 conversion, (b) CO2 conversion, (c) the corresponding ratio of H2/CO and (d) the activity retention and the rate of CH4 consumption after last hour on stream. Reaction conditions: 1.0 atm, T = 800 ℃, CH4: CO2: N2= 1:1:3, mcat. = 24 mg, GHSV = 250 L·g−1·h−1. Fig 4 Fig. 5 XRD patterns of spent catalysts (a), TEM images for NiMo-HMgO-2s (b), NiMo-HMgO-3s (c) and NiMo-HMgO-1s (d) with corresponding EDS mapping of Ni, Mo, Mg and O elements. Fig 5 Fig. 6 XPS spectra for Ni 2p3/2 (a), Mo 3d (b) and C 1s (c) of NiMo-HMgO-1s and NiMo-HMgO-2s. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (a) Raman spectra of NiMo-HMgO-1s, NiMo-HMgO-2s and NiMo-H MgO-3s. (b) The identity and amounts of deposited carbon derived from sequential CO2- and Air-TGA measurements of spent NiMo-HMgO-2 and NiMo-HMgO-1. CO2 reforming with methane (DRM) is a potential effective carbon neutralization strategy to convert greenhouse gases into syngas. The key to the DRM process is to design active and coking resistant catalysts. Herein, hollow hierarchical bimetallic NiMo-HMgO catalysts were prepared via hydrothermal-impregnation method. The prepared NiMo-HMgO catalysts exhibited higher catalytic performance during the DRM process than commercial NiMo-CMgO catalysts, due to the formation of Ni-Mo-MgO composite on hierarchical MgO (HMgO), which is promoted by exposed (111) polar surface of HMgO with alternate arrangement of anion and cation layers. The deposited carbon and stability can be effectively regulated by adjusting the amount of Ni and the molar ratio of Mo/(Ni+Mo). The synergistic effect of metal and HMgO can provide reference for the research in other related fields. Graphical abstract The self-assembled Ni-Mo-MgO on hierarchical MgO (HMgO) is formed and promote the catalytic performance. Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 reforming with methane Hierarchical MgO Ni-Mo-MgO Deposited carbon Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The CO2 reforming with methane has attracted extensive attention due to its potential to convert two greenhouse gases into syngas [1–3] (CO:H2=1:1), which is used as raw material to synthesize methanol and other raw chemical materials through F-T synthesis [4,5]. The key to DRM is to prepare effective catalysts, which are commonly composed by active components such as Pt, Ru, Ni and Co etc. loaded on various supports [6–9]. Compared with noble metal and other transition metal catalysts, nickel-based catalysts are more appropriate due to its lower cost, relatively high activity, and good selectivity for DRM. However, the activity of nickel-based catalysts usually declines during reaction owing to the following two reasons: One is carbon deposition on the surface of the active metal sites, and the other is sintering of metal under high temperatures. Therefore, some strategies, including using basic support (MgO [10]) or support rich in oxygen vacancies (CeO2 [11]), building strong metal-support interaction (SIMS) [12], addition of promoters (K [13], Sn [14], La2O3 [15,16] and CaO [17] etc.), alloying (Fe [18,19], Co [20] and Mn [21] etc.), building structure of local restriction [22,23], have been adopted to alleviate carbon deposition. It was found that the catalysts with fine particles uniformly dispersed on the supports help decrease carbon deposition [24]. As an alkaline earth metal oxide, MgO is widely used to promote the adsorption of CO2 and the elimination of deposited carbon during the DRM because of its abundant basic sites. In some studies, MgO was used as a promoter to neutralize the acidity of the catalysts [17,25–27], which can improve the catalytic activity of metals. As a support, MgO has attracted extensive interest of researchers in recent decades. Hu et al. [28] reported that the H2-reduced NiO-MgO catalyst exhibited better catalytic activity and stability over NiO-BaO (CaO, SrO), which can be attributed to the formation of stable solid solution due to Ni2+ and Mg2+ have close ionic radius [6]. Song et al. [29] developed a “Nanocatalysts On Single Crystal Edges” (NOSCE) technique, in which the single-crystalline MgO edges could inhibit sintering and maintain the catalytic activity of Ni-Mo nanoparticles and effectively eliminate carbon deposits for continuous reaction over 850 h. Cheng et al. [30] deposited Ni nanoparticles on MgO support by “Nanocrystal On Porous Single-crystalline Monoliths” (PSC) strategy, which showed good structure stability, coking resistance and high activity at 700 ℃ for 500 h, where high crystallinity of MgO could alter the expected redox reaction between methyl species (CH3*) and CO2 to alleviate carbon deposition. It is a feasible potential strategy for DRM to design suitable structure of MgO support. In our previous report [31,32], a hierarchical MgO (HMgO) exposed (111) polar crystal planes possessing abundant pore structures, large amount of basic sites has been prepared, which has exhibited excellent catalytic activity for acetone condensation to mesityl oxide and isophorone at low temperatures and Claisen-Schmidt condensation reaction. A hierarchical Ni/MgO catalyst was successfully prepared, and exhibited high activity and thermal stability for CO2 methanation [33]. As a promoter, Mo is useful to improve catalytic stability and inhibit carbon deposition during reaction [34]. However, some studies found that the formation of MoNi4 during reduction decreased initial activity of Ni-Mo bimetallic catalysts [35,36]. The introduction of oxygen was useful to regulate the dynamic structure between Ni-Mo alloy and NiMoxOy, and improved catalytic activity [29]. To our knowledge, Ni-MgO solid solution is helpful to promote the formation of oxygen vacancies, inhibit the sintering of Ni nanoparticles and alleviate carbon deposition [28,37–39]. Thus, the structure of Ni-Mo-MgO, as active integral catalytic systems, can be loaded on HMgO for DRM. Herein, hollow hierarchical bimetallic NiMo-HMgO catalysts were successfully synthesized via hydrothermal-impregnation method. The structure change of active components Ni-Mo-MgO and the catalytic activity and stability of NiMo-HMgO catalysts for DRM were studied. The influence of Mo/(Ni+Mo) molar ratio for catalysts were studied. 2 Experiment 2.1 Materials Magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, AR, fuchen), urea (CO(NH2)2, AR, Sinopharm Chemical), nickel chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O, AR, Aladdin), ammonium Molybdate Tetrahydrate (H24Mo7N6O24·4H2O, AR, Macklin), polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP, AR, Mw = 55,000, Aladdin), commercial MgO (CMgO, AR, Xilong Chemical), hydrazine hydrate (N2H4·H2O, AR, Sinopharm Chemical) and ethylene glycol ((CH2OH)2, AR, Aladdin) were purchased and used as received. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The hierarchical MgO (HMgO) was synthesized by the hydrothermal method [31]. In a typical synthesis procedure, 2.56 g of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and 6.00 g of urea were dissolved in 50 mL deionized water. The obtained homogeneous liquid was transferred into a 100 mL polytetrafluoroethylene lining stainless steel autoclave and sealed. The autoclave was transferred into baking oven and maintained at 200 ℃ for 9 h. After cooling, the white powder at the bottom of the autoclave was filtered and dried at 105 ℃ to obtain the precursor. The precursor was calcined at 500 ℃ (ramp rate = 5 ℃·min−1) for 5 h in muffle furnace to obtain the sample denoted as HMgO. The Ni based catalysts were synthesized by the polyol method [29]. 0.404 g of NiCl2·6H2O and 36.8 mg of H24Mo7N6O24·4H2O were dissolved in the solution of ethylene glycol/deionized water (24:1 vol ratio, 25 mL). 0.38 g of PVP was added under vigorous stirring to form the homogeneous solution. Then, 0.50 g of HMgO was added to the solution and the as obtained suspension was heated to 80 ℃. After that, 5 mL of hydrazine monohydrate/ethylene glycol solution (5.11 M) and 10 mL of sodium hydroxide/ethylene glycol solution (0.34 M) were added in sequence, and kept at 80 ℃ for 1 h. Subsequently, the mixture was cooled down to room temperature and subjected to vacuum filtration. The filter cake was washed three times with ethylene glycol and ethanol, respectively. This catalyst was named as NiMo-HMgO-1. NiMo-HMgO-2 and NiMo-HMgO-3 were prepared with the same procedure except for adding 0.90 g and 0.25 g of HMgO, respectively instead. To explore the structure-effect relationship of MgO, a commercial MgO was also used for comparison. NiMo-CMgO-1 and NiMo-CMgO-2 were prepared with the same procedure in NiMo-HMgO synthesis by adding 0.50 g or 0.90 g CMgO, respectively. To identify the role of Mo in catalyst, Ni-HMgO-1 and Mo- HMgO-1 were synthesized with the same method without adding Mo precursor and Ni precursor, respectively. NiMo-HMgO-4 and NiMo-HMgO-5 were also synthesized with the same method with adding 0.02 g and 0.3 g Mo precursor, respectively. The activated samples were named as NiMo-H(C)MgO-xa, and spent samples were named as NiMo-H(C)MgO-xs. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The characterizations of X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, scanning electron microscope (SEM), transmission electron microscope (TEM), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman spectra, thermal analyzer (TGA) and detailed operations were shown in Supplementary Information. 2.4 Catalytic testing The catalytic performance of catalysts was carried out on a fixed-bed U-shaped quartz reactor (6 mm i.d.). In each test, 24 mg catalyst was placed in the reactor and sealed with quartz wool. When the temperature reached 800 ℃ (ramp rate =10 ℃·min−1), 75 mL min−1 20 % H2/N2 gas mixture was switched to pretreat the catalyst for one hour. After that, the mixed gas (CH4: CO2: N2=1:1:3) with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 250 L·g−1·h−1 was introduced to the reactor. The effluent gas was analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (M3000). The conversions of CH4 and CO2, the ratio of H2/CO, the activity retention and the rate of CH4 consumption were calculated by eq.1, eq.2, eq.3, eq.4 and eq.5, respectively. (1) X C H 4 ( % ) = F C H 4 , i n − F C H 4 , o u t F C H 4 , i n × 100 (2) X C O 2 ( % ) = F C O 2 , i n − F C O 2 , o u t F C O 2 , i n × 100 (3) H 2 C O = F H 2 , o u t F C O , o u t (4) A C = X l C H 4 / C O 2 X h C H 4 / C O 2 (5) R C H 4 = F C H 4 , i n × X C H 4 × 60 m c × W n i × 22.4 × 10 3 where F i , i n (mol·min−1) and F i , o u t (mol·min−1) are the inlet and outlet molar flow rate of species i (i = CO2, CH4, H2 and CO), respectively. X l C H 4 / C O 2 and X h C H 4 / C O 2 are the conversion of CH4 or CO2 at last, the highest conversion of CH4 or CO2, respectively. X C H 4 (%), m c (g) and W n i (wt.%) are the conversion of CH4, the weight of catalyst, nickel metal loading, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts The crystalline phase and morphology of the HMgO and CMgO were identified by XRD and SEM, and the results were shown in Fig. S1 and S2. HMgO and CMgO have similar diffraction peaks at 36.94°, 42.92°, 62.3°, 74.7° and 78.6°, corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), (311) and (222) planes of MgO (JCPDS 45-0946), respectively. Three diffraction peaks of CMgO at 18.53°, 37.98° and 50.79° are assigned to (001), (101) and (102) planes of Mg(OH)2 (JCPDS 44-1482), respectively. As shown in Fig. S2b and S2c, the HMgO is a gyroscope like micro buck whose surface coated with nano octahedral, which is consistent with our previous researches [6,31]. The CMgO is composed of irregular beads and two-dimensional flakes compiled together with a diameter and thickness of about 1.2 μm and 100 nm, respectively (Fig. S2a). For the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of supports (Fig. S3), the specific surface area of HMgO (104.72 m2·g−1) is much higher than that of the CMgO (20.28 m2·g−1). The HMgO shows a H1-shaped hysteresis loop with a narrow pore-size distribution centered at 7.85 nm, revealing that HMgO possesses uniform mesoporous structure. While the CMgO has a wide pore-size distribution around 3.80 and 12.58 nm, which is caused by the accumulation of particles and flakes. The crystalline phase of the fresh catalysts was confirmed by XRD, and the patterns were shown in Fig. 1 a. The diffraction peaks at 44.51°, 51.85° and 76.37° correspond to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of Ni (JCPDS 04-0850), respectively, indicating that Ni particles are loaded on supports. While the corresponding peaks of (111) planes at 44.13° and 44.22° for NiMo-HMgO-1 and NiMo-CMgO-1, respectively are assigned by shifting from 44.51° for pristine Ni towards lower angles, indicating that Mo replaces a small portion of Ni and distorts the bulk phase of Ni, through which Ni-Mo alloy is formed. The NiMo-HMgO-1 also has a diffraction peak at 59.43°, corresponding to the (212) plane of Ni3Mo (JCPDS 17-0572), indicating that Ni3Mo appears on NiMo-HMgO-1. The prepared NiMo-CMgO-1 and NiMo-HMgO-1 were further analyzed by TEM and EDS mapping to explore the morphology and elements distribution on supports. Compared to CMgO, the spheroid particles are obviously observed on NiMo-CMgO-1 as white spots in dark field image (Fig. 2 a). The sizes of spheroid particles vary from 300 to 400 nm for NiMo-CMgO-1, and Ni and Mo elements are detected on spherical particles in corresponding EDS mapping images, suggesting that the spheroid particles are Ni-Mo alloy. As shown in Fig. 2b, NiMo-HMgO-1 catalyst shows an ordered mesoporous structure, and the corresponding EDS mapping images show that the Ni and Mo are uniformly distributed on the HMgO support. To evaluate the metal-support interaction of the NiMo-CMgO-1 and NiMo-HMgO-1 (2), H2-TPR was conducted. As shown in Fig. S4, the reduction peaks below and high 400 ℃ of NiMo-CMgO-1 and NiMo-HMgO-1 (2) are scribed to the reduction of the outermost layer Ni2+ close to MgO or the highly dispersed Ni2+ on MgO and the reduction of Ni2+in the lattice matrix of MgO, respectively [40,41]. The results indicate that NiMo-HMgO-1 (2) has a strong Ni-MgO interaction than NiMo-CMgO-1. After being activated, the samples are charactered by a series of characterizations. The specific surface area and Ni dispersion of activated catalysts are shown in Table 1 . The specific surface area of NiMo-HMgO-1a, NiMo-HMgO-2a and NiMo-CMgO-1a are 42.38, 41.83 and 22.71 m2·g−1, respectively. However, the specific surface area of NiMo-HMgO-a catalysts significantly decrease compared to HMgO, indicating that part of the pores of the support is blocked. The NiMo-HMgO-1a shows the highest specific surface area and Ni dispersion (0.53 %), which is helpful to improve the catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. 1b, no peaks of Mo phase are observed, and the Ni3Mo phase disappears from NiMo-HMgO-1a, revealing that Mo further diffuse into the bulk phase of Ni after activation. The lattice constants of Ni on NiMo-HMgO-1a, NiMo-HMgO-2a, NiMo-CMgO-1a and NiMo-CMgO-2a expand from 3.523 to 3.548, 3.556, 3.549 and 3.548 Å, respectively (Fig. S5 and Table S1). This result shows that the structures of Ni-Mo alloy still maintain on all catalysts. The microscopic properties of activated samples were studied using SEM and TEM. NiMo-CMgO-a samples still maintain the similar structure with unactivated samples (Fig. S6). Compared with NiMo-HMgO-x, spheroid particles are observed on activated samples (Fig. 3 ). The produced spheroid particles of NiMo-HMgO-1a are further studied by EDS mapping. It can be observed that these spheroid particles are hollow with diameter ranging from 200 to 300 nm and composed of Ni, Mo, Mg and O elements (Fig. 3c and d). However, the walls of spheroid like particles on NiMo-HMgO-2a are much thicker (Fig. 3a and b). The particles tend to form hollow structures when the agglomeration speed is faster than the growth speed during the heating process. The hollow structure is conducive to increase the dispersion of Ni and improve the catalytic activity [42]. The mapping images further reveal that Mg and O are involved in the diffusion growth of the Ni-Mo alloy and form a self-assembled structure of Ni-Mo-MgO. The formation of Ni-Mo-MgO may be related to layered alternating arrangement polar planes of HMgO surface nano octahedrons, in which the migration of Mg and O ions is easier than those of other planes. Compared with the NiMo-CMgO-a, the structure of Ni-Mo-MgO on NiMo-HMgO-a is obviously modified, which may improve catalytic activity [43]. 3.2 Catalytic performance assessments The stability evaluation of the NiMo-HMgO and NiMo-CMgO catalysts were conducted, and the conversions of CH4 and CO2 and the H2/CO ratio with time on stream for DRM were depicted in Fig. 4 a-c. For the NiMo-CMgO-2, the conversions of CH4 and CO2 rapidly decrease during 36 h testing from 61.06 %, 73.65 % to 37.19 %, 46.07 %, respectively. For the NiMo-CMgO-1, the conversions of CH4 and CO2 remain around 62.88 % and 69.56 % during 40 h testing. For the NiMo-HMgO-2, the initial conversions of CH4 and CO2 are 82.26 % and 88.68 %, and decrease to 66.72 % and 77.56 % after 70 h testing, respectively. For the NiMo-HMgO-3, the conversions of CH4 and CO2 remain around 61.49 % and 68.63 % during 40 h testing. The NiMo-HMgO-1 exhibits the best catalytic activity and stability for over 100 h, in which the conversions of CH4 and CO2 remain around 79.25 % and 85.51 %, respectively. It can be concluded that adjusting the Ni and Mo (M) amount can improve the catalytic performance. As the M amount increases, the catalytic stability of the catalysts increases, while the catalytic activity decreases. Meanwhile, it is noted that the active components of catalysts need about 6 h to reach an optimal state. During this induction period, Metallic Ni is oxidized by CO2 at initial stage, and is reduced back to Ni by the produced H2 from CH4 [18]. The H2/CO ratio at 32 h over NiMo-CMgO-2, NiMo-CMgO-1, NiMo-HMgO-2, NiMo-HMgO-3 and NiMo-HMgO-1 are 0.63, 0.84, 0.92, 0.89 and 0.90, respectively (Fig. 4c), indicating that reverse water-gas shift (RWGH, CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O) takes place in DRM, which consumes H2 to produce H2O. The NiMo-HMgO catalysts show better catalytic activity and stability than NiMo-CMgO catalysts, indicating that the HMgO is superior than CMgO in improving the catalytic performance. The deactivation of catalysts after reaction was further analyzed and the result was shown in Fig. 4d. The activity retention of CH4 on NiMo-HMgO-1, NiMo-HMgO-2, NiMo-HMgO-3 and NiMo-CMgO-1 is 93.97 %, 80.46 %, 95.25 % and 93.08 %, in which the corresponding activity retention of CO2 is 94.23 %, 87.10 %, 95.69 % and 92.90 %, respectively. The rate of CH4 consumption for NiMo-HMgO-1, NiMo-HMgO-2, NiMo-HMgO-3 and NiMo-CMgO-1 is 14.29, 18.55, 4.40 and 8.60 mol·g−1·h−1 in turn. The NiMo-HMgO catalysts show the higher activity retention of CH4 and CO2 and rate of CH4 consumption compared with other catalysts. Wherein, the NiMo-HMgO-1 shows the highest activity retention of CH4 and CO2 and the higher rate of CH4 consumption after a 100 h DRM, suggesting that the hollow spheroid particles of Ni-Mo-MgO could maintain the catalytic performance in the reaction. 3.3 Characterizations of the spent catalysts and deposited carbon The crystalline structure of spent catalysts along with their deposited carbon were characterized by XRD and TEM, and the lattice constants of all catalysts were shown in Table S1 in detail. Compared with the activated catalysts, the spent catalysts still have similar diffraction peaks (Fig. 5 a and Fig. S7), implying that catalysts maintain original structure after reaction. Wherein, the NiMo-HMgO-1s shows the smallest peak shift than those of other catalysts, demonstrating that the structure of Ni-Mo-MgO is stable during DRM testing. The diffraction peak of the NiMo-HMgO-1s and NiMo-HMgO-3s (Fig. S8) at about 26° is assigned to (003) plane of graphitic carbon, suggesting that graphitic carbon has been produced in the reaction. As shown in Fig. 5b-d, no carbon nanotubes are observed in NiMo-HMgO-2s. And the amorphous carbon and carbon nanotubes are observed on the NiMo-HMgO-3s and NiMo-HMgO-1s. These results indicate that deposited carbon is produced during reaction. As shown in EDS mapping images of NiMo-HMgO-1s, Ni, Mo, Mg, O elements are identified, where Ni and Mo are evenly distributed in MgO, indicating that the Ni-Mo-MgO maintains the original structure. The surface compositions and valence states of activated and spent catalysts were further analyzed by XPS. As shown in Fig. S9a, the peaks of Ni 2p3/2 spectra of NiMo-HMgO-a catalysts at around 852.3 eV, 855.2 eV, 857.4 eV are assigned to surface Ni0, Ni2+ and Ni3+ species, respectively [34,44]. After DRM, the Ni 2p3/2 spectra of NiMo-HMgO catalysts (Fig. 6 a) show Ni2+ and Ni3+ species with corresponding binding energies at abound 855.6 eV and 857.5 eV, respectively [34,44]. These results indicate that the surface of Ni is oxidized after reaction [23,45]. As shown in Fig. S9b and Fig. 6b, the peaks of activated and spent NiMo-HMgO catalysts at around 228.5 eV, 231.5 eV and 233.1 eV are attributed to Mo0, Mo5+ and Mo6+ species, respectively, which shows that the Mo still remains the same oxidation state before and after reaction, indicating that the Mo still exists in Ni-Mo-MgO structure [34]. The peaks of C 1s spectra of NiMo-HMgO-s (Fig. 6c) at 284.6 eV, 286.0 eV and 289.6 eV could be assigned to graphite, CO and CO3 2− types of carbonaceous species [18,46]. Hence, it is concluded that deposited carbon occurs on the surface of spent catalysts. To investigate the graphitization degree of deposited carbon on spent catalysts, Raman spectra were conducted. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the peaks at about 1334 cm−1 and 1580 cm−1 are assigned to D-band and G-band signals, which are attributed to disordered carbon and graphite carbon [6], respectively. Compared to disordered carbon, graphite carbon is more difficult to eliminate in DRM due to its lower activity. The peak intensity ratio of the D-band and G-band signals (IG/ID) is used to reflect the graphitization degree of deposited carbon [34]. Compared with NiMo-HMgO-1s and NiMo-HMgO-2s (0.985, 1.021), the value of IG/ID of NiMo-HMgO-3s is the largest (1.330), indicating that the graphitization degree of deposited carbon generated on NiMo-HMgO-3 is the highest. The amounts and types of deposited carbon on spent catalysts were analyzed by TGA under CO2 and air conditions. Soft carbonaceous species (called soft carbon) can be gasified by CO2, while refractory carbonaceous species (called refractory carbon) can be removed under air atmosphere. The soft carbon for spent NiMo-HMgO-1 and NiMo-HMgO-2 are 37.3 % and 10.3 %, and the corresponding refractory carbon are 2.61 % and 1.11 %, respectively (Fig 7b). The average carbon deposition rates and refractory carbon deposition rates of spent NiMo-HMgO-2 and NiMo-HMgO-1 were calculated and shown in Fig. 8 . The NiMo-HMgO-2 shows a lower refractory carbon deposition rate (0.15 mg⋅gcat −1⋅h−1) and carbon deposition rate (1.75 mg⋅gcat −1⋅h−1). The NiMo-HMgO-1 shows a higher refractory carbon deposition rate (0.27 mg⋅gcat −1⋅h−1) and carbon deposition rate (6.65 mg⋅gcat −1⋅h−1). However, the NiMo-CMgO-1s has the highest refractory carbon deposition rate (0.29 mg⋅gcat −1⋅h−1) (Fig. S10). Combining the above analysis results, the increase of M content increases the amount of deposited carbon, and the HMgO has better resistance to refractory carbon than CMgO. Zhu et al. [47] reported a similar result that the amount of deposited carbon increases with the increase of Ni content. The deposited carbon couldn't be avoided over nickel-supported catalysts during DRM. The pyrolytic, encapsulating and whisker carbon are three types of deposited carbon, but not all types of deposited carbon led to deactivation of the catalysts. When the active components of catalysts were completely encapsulated by deposited carbon, activity would rapidly decline or even disappear [9,48–50]. The produced NiMo-HMgO-1 has a strong interaction between Ni and MgO, and the strong interaction of Ni and MgO can carry away carbon nanotube from the Ni particles during the growth process of carbon nanotube [35], which has lower effect on the catalytic activity, so the catalytic activity and stability can be maintained. 3.4 Deposited carbon formation-elimination mechanism on DRM On the basis of NiMo-HMgO-1 catalyst, three other catalysts with different Mo/(Ni+Mo) molar ratios for catalytic activity are explored and the results are shown in Fig. 9 a and b. For the Ni-HMgO-1, the conversions of CH4 and CO2 rapidly decrease during 8 h testing from 32.06 %, 39.95 % to 24.81 %, 29.98 %, respectively. For the NiMo-HMgO-4, the conversions of CH4 and CO2 decrease from 80.57 %, 83.58 % to 71.92 %, 81.11 % during 9 h testing, respectively. For the NiMo-HMgO-5, the conversions of CH4 and CO2 increase from 13.03 %, 25.39 % to 22.09 %, 28.89 % during 20 h testing, respectively. The conversions of CH4 and CO2 of Mo-HMgO-1 are found to be less than 10 % during 8 h testing. The different Mo/(Ni+Mo) molar ratios are obtained based on Ni-HMgO-1, NiMo-HMgO-1, NiMo-HMgO-4, NiMo-HMgO-5 and Mo-HMgO-1, and the corresponding initial conversion rate of CH4 and CO2 are shown in Fig. 9c. The catalytic activity of catalysts with different Mo/(Ni+Mo) molar ratios decreased in the following sequence: NiMo-HMgO-1 > NiMo-HMgO-4 > Ni-HMgO-1 > NiMo-HMgO-5 > Mo-HMgO-1, indicating that the adding of Mo/(Ni+Mo) molar ratio is useful to improve the catalytic activity, but the further increase of Mo/(Ni+Mo) molar ratio actually reduces the catalytic activity. The microscopic properties of spent NiMo-HMgO-5 were obtained by SEM with EDS mapping. As shown in Fig. S11, particles are observed on sample surface, and further Mapping images show that Ni, Mo, Mg and O elements are uniformly distributed on the surface of spent NiMo-HMgO-5. Meanwhile, C element is also detected. The diffraction peaks (Fig. 10 a) at 39.3°, 52.1°, 69.5° are ascribed to Mo2C (JCPDS 35-0787), indicating that carbon species is generated during reaction, which is consistent with SEM analysis. The Raman spectra (Fig. 10b) shows that the value of IG/ID is 0.794, indicating that the graphitization degree of carbon species on spent NiMo-HMgO-5 is low. The Ni2Mo3O8 phase is also observed on XRD pattern (Fig. 10a), indicating that oxygen species of Mo (MoxOy) is produced during reaction. Combined with the experimental results, a possible deposited carbon formation-elimination mechanism (Scheme 1 ) is proposed: CH4 is dissociated on Ni surface to form the intermediate of CHx* (x = 0–3) and H*, and the CHx* is further dissociated to form Cα (atomic carbon) and H*. On the one hand, Cα reacts with MoxOy to form Mo2C, and Mo2C further reacts with CO2 or O* to form CO and MoxOy, which realizes the cycle of MoxOy and Mo2C. On the other hand, the produced Cα can also polymerize to from Cβ, and the Cα and Cβ are easily eliminated by CO2 or O* [18,51,52]. The nucleation, growth and diffusion of Cβ further form whisker carbon [53], and the whisker carbon is difficult to eliminate. 4 Conclusions In summary, the NiMo-HMgO catalysts were successfully prepared, and the Ni and Mo were found to be homogeneously distributed on catalysts. The self-assembled Ni-Mo-MgO on HMgO was formed, which might be related to layered alternating arrangement polar planes of HMgO. Compared with the other catalysts, the NiMo-HMgO-1 exhibited the best catalytic activity (over 80 %) and stability for 100 h DRM testing. The formation of Ni-Mo-MgO on HMgO is useful to improve the catalytic performance of NiMo-HMgO catalysts. Furthermore, adjusting the amount of Ni and the molar ratio of Mo/(Ni+Mo) on NiMo-HMgO catalysts can effectively regulate catalysis activity and deposited carbon. coredata.dc:description: CO2 reforming with methane (DRM) is a potential effective carbon neutralization strategy to convert greenhouse gases into syngas. The key to the DRM process is to design active and coking resistant catalysts. Herein, hollow hierarchical bimetallic NiMo-HMgO catalysts were prepared via hydrothermal-impregnation method. The prepared NiMo-HMgO catalysts exhibited higher catalytic performance during the DRM process than commercial NiMo-CMgO catalysts, due to the formation of Ni-Mo-MgO composite on hierarchical MgO (HMgO), which is promoted by exposed (111) polar surface of HMgO with alternate arrangement of anion and cation layers. The deposited carbon and stability can be effectively regulated by adjusting the amount of Ni and the molar ratio of Mo/(Ni+Mo). The synergistic effect of metal and HMgO can provide reference for the research in other related fields.
